DOC.HEAD: Agents Probe Slaying Of Federal Judge Killed By Mail Bomb

Eds: SUBS grafs 5-6, `Asked whether ...,' with 2 grafs to CLARIFY that Moore was asked whether death was connected to drug cases, DELETE extraneous word `he' from 6th graf; picks up 7th graf, `U.S. Marshal ...'
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents Sunday searched the secluded estate of a federal judge killed by a mail bomb delivered to his home. Investigators said a drug-related motive was one possibility being examined. Robert S. Vance, an 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals judge, was killed instantly when the package exploded Saturday afternoon in the kitchen of his suburban Birmingham home, authorities said. His wife, Helen, was injured and remained hospitalized Sunday in serious condition. Vance, 58, a progressive force in Alabama during 11 years as state chairman of the Democratic Party, was the third federal judge to be assassinated in 10 years. The three are believed to be the only federal jurists killed this century. FBI spokesman Tom Moore said there were ``specific leads'' but declined to elaborate, saying only that investigators were pursuing numerous possibilities. Asked whether Vance's death was connected to drug cases handled by his court, ``It is not being ruled out, but it is no more prominent than several other avenues we are following. We are reviewing his full case load.'' Agent Allen Whitaker said every FBI agent in the Birmingham area was working on the case. He said many details could not disclosed because of the ``very rapid, breaking nature of this investigation.'' U.S. Marshal Thomas C. Greene said Vance had not asked for protection and the marshal's office was not aware of any threats on his life. Greene would not say whether security has been increased for judges because of the slaying. Asked about security for other federal judges, Moore said, ``They have been warned,'' but declined to say if any were under guard. Judges may request security at any time, he added. Vance, appointed to the federal appeals court in 1977, served in a circuit that reviewed cases from Florida, Georgia and Alabama. ``As a member of the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals, they heard many appeal cases related to drugs from Miami,'' Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., a longtime friend of Vance, said Saturday. ``There's speculation in that regard, but nobody knows.'' The circuit has 12 judges, as well as six judges on senior, or semi-retired, status. The judges generally serve on three-judge panels that review rulings made by trial-level courts. In Miami, U.S. District Judge Lawrence King said if Vance's death were related to drug trafficking, ``you would be more apt to see this type of violence directed toward a judge or magistrate at the trial level in Florida, or perhaps Alabama. ``But who knows?'' King told The Birmingham News. Vance's two-story home in Birmingham's most exclusive suburb was cordoned off Sunday as federal and local authorities searched it. Whitaker said FBI agents and postal inspectors spoke with Mrs. Vance at the hospital, and she ``has provided information that will be helpful in an investigation.'' Whitaker said Mrs. Vance apparently was not standing close to her husband when the bomb exploded. She was able to call a neighbor, who then summoned police to the home, Moore said. ``Indications are that it was delivered by regular U.S. mail,'' not special delivery, Moore said. Moore said Vance's family was being guarded, but declined to give details. The couple, which had been married 36 years, had two sons, Robert S. Vance Jr., a Birmingham lawyer, and Charles Vance, whose residence wasn't known immediately. Whitaker and Jefferson County District Attorney David Barber joined investigators inside the home on a narrow, curving road lined by houses set deep in wooded estates. Vance was appointed to the federal appeals court in 1977 by President Carter and took his seat the following year. He continued to live and work in the Birmingham area, although the court is based in Atlanta. As state Democratic Party chairman from 1966 to 1977, Vance was a force for racial moderation, fighting off attacks by then-Gov. George C. Wallace against the national Democratic Party. In 1974, Wallace sought to wrest control of the state party from Vance, but in a secret ballot in Birmingham, Vance turned back Wallace's handpicked choice for chairman. ``He was a voice of sanity in turbulent times and a leader of reasoned action,'' said Heflin, who met Vance more than 30 years ago when they were young trial lawyers. ``Alabama and America's jurisprudence has suffered a tremendous loss.'' It was believed that only two other federal judges have been assassinated this century. U.S. District Judge Richard Daronco, 56, was shot and killed at his home in Pelham, N.Y., in 1988 by a former policeman angry at Daronco's dismissal of a sex discrimination lawsuit filed by his daughter. Charles Koster, 67, killed himself after gunning down the judge. District Judge John H. Wood Jr., 63, was killed by a sniper outside his home in San Antonio in 1979. Charles Voyed Harrelson was convicted of the contract killing and is serving two life sentences in a Texas prison. El Paso drug trafficker Jamiel ``Jimmy'' Chagra, who authorities say ordered the hit, was convicted of conspiring to obstruct the investigation of Wood's murder and various drug charges. He is serving a life sentence in federal prison. Chagra had been scheduled to go on trial on drug charges before Wood the day the judge was slain.
